00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 parserPrime.pl - defines a prime operator (') to perform differentiation
00020                  (can be used in student answers as well).
00021 
00022 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00023 
00024 This file defines the code necessary to make the prime (') operator perform
00025 differentiation within a Formula object.  For example, Formula("(x^2)'") would
00026 equal Formula("2*x"), and Formula("(x^2)''") would equal Real(2).  The context
00027 also includes reduction rules to replace the prime notaiton by the actual
00028 derivative.
00029 
00030 To accomplish this, put the line
00031 
00032     loadMacros("parserPrime.pl");
00033 
00034 at the beginning of your problem file, then set the Context to the one you wish
00035 to use in the problem.  Then use the command:
00036 
00037     parser::Prime->Enable;
00038 
00039 (You can also pass the Enable command a context pointer if you wish to
00040 alter a context other than the current one.)
00041 
00042 Once this is done, you will be able to enter primes in your Formulas
00043 to refer to differentiation.  For example:
00044 
00045     Formula("(3x^2+2x+1)'")
00046 
00047 would mean the derivative of 3x^2+2x+1 and would be equivalent to
00048 
00049     Formula("3*2*x+2")
00050 
00051 The variable of differentiation is taken from the variables used in
00052 the formula being differentiated.  If there is more than one variable
00053 used, the first one alphabetically is used.  For example
00054 
00055     Formula("(ln(x))' + (x^2+3y)'")
00056 
00057 would produce the equivalent to
00058 
00059     Formula("(1/x) + (2*x+0)").
00060 
00061 This can have unexpected results, however, since.
00062 
00063     Formula("(x^2)' + (y^2)'")
00064 
00065 would generate
00066 
00067     Formula("2*x + 2*y")
00068 
00069 which may not be what you want.  In order to specify the variable for
00070 differentiation, you can list it in the Enable() call.  For example:
00071 
00072     parser::Prime->Enable("x");
00073 
00074 would make
00075 
00076     Formula("(x^2)' + (y^2)'")
00077 
00078 generate
00079 
00080     Formula("2*x + 0")
00081 
00082 rather than the default 2x+2y.
00083 
00084 The prime operator also defines a reduction rule that allows the prime
00085 notation to be replaced by the actual derivative when the Formula is
00086 reduced.  This is off by default, but you can set it via
00087 
00088     Context()->reduction->set("(f)'"=>1);
00089 
00090 so that it will be on for all reductions, or specify it for a single
00091 reduction as follows:
00092 
00093     $f = Formula("(x^2)'")->reduce("(f)'"=>1);
00094 
00095 to obtain $f as Formula("2*x").
00096 
00097 Note that once the prime has been added to the Context, student
00098 answers will be allowed to include primes as well, so if you want
00099 students to actually perform the differentiation themselves, you may
00100 wish to disable the prime at the end of the problem (so it will not be
00101 active while student answers are being parsed).  To do that use
00102 
00103     parser::Prime->Disable;
00104 
00105 (You can pass Disable a context pointer to remove the prime operator
00106 from a context other than the current one.)
00107 
00108 =cut
00109 
00110 sub _parserPrime_init {};    # don't load a second time
00111 
00112 ##########################################
00113 #
00114 #  Package to enable and disable the prime operator
00115 #
00116 package parser::Prime;
00117 
00118 #
00119 #  Add prime to the given or current context
00120 #
00121 sub Enable {
00122   my $self = shift; my $x = shift;
00123   my $context = main::Context();
00124   if (Value::isContext($x)) {$context = $x; $x = shift}
00125   $context->operators->add("'"=>{
00126     precedence => 8.5, associativity => "right", type => "unary", string => "'",
00127     class => "parser::Prime::UOP::prime", isCommand => 1
00128   });
00129   $context->reduction->set("(f)'" => 0);
00130   $context->flags->set(prime_variable => $x) if defined($x);
00131 }
00132 
00133 #
00134 #  Remove prime from the context
00135 #
00136 sub Disable {
00137   my $self = shift; my $context = shift || main::Context();
00138   $context->operators->remove("'");
00139 }
00140 
00141 ##########################################
00142 #
00143 #  Prime operator is a subclass of the unary operator class
00144 #
00145 package parser::Prime::UOP::prime;
00146 our @ISA = ('Parser::UOP');
00147 
00148 #
00149 #  Do a typecheck on the operand
00150 #
00151 sub _check {
00152   my $self = shift;
00153   return if $self->checkInfinite || $self->checkString ||
00154             $self->checkList || $self->checkNumber;
00155   $self->{type} = {%{$self->{op}->typeRef}};
00156 }
00157 
00158 #
00159 #  A hack to prevent double-primes from inserting parentheses
00160 #   in string and TeX output (change the precedence to hide it)
00161 #
00162 sub string {
00163   my ($self,$precedence,$showparens,$position,$outerRight) = @_;
00164   my $uop = $self->{def}; $precedence -= .01 if $uop->{precedence} == $precedence;
00165   return $self->SUPER::string($precedence,$showparens,$position,$outerRight);
00166 }
00167 sub TeX {
00168   my ($self,$precedence,$showparens,$position,$outerRight) = @_;
00169   my $uop = $self->{def}; $precedence -= .01 if $uop->{precedence} == $precedence;
00170   return $self->SUPER::TeX($precedence,$showparens,$position,$outerRight);
00171 }
00172 
00173 #
00174 #  Produce a perl version of the derivative
00175 #
00176 sub perl {
00177   my $self = shift;
00178   return $self->{op}->D($self->getVar)->perl;
00179 }
00180 
00181 #
00182 #  Evaluate the derivative
00183 #
00184 sub eval {
00185   my $self = shift;
00186   return $self->{op}->D($self->getVar)->eval;
00187 }
00188 
00189 #
00190 #  Reduce by replacing with derivative
00191 #
00192 sub reduce {
00193   my $self = shift;
00194   return $self unless $self->context->{reduction}{"(f)'"};
00195   return $self->{op}->D($self->getVar);
00196 }
00197 
00198 sub getVar {
00199   my $self = shift;
00200   return $self->context->flag("prime_variable") ||
00201          (keys(%{$self->getVariables}))[0] ||
00202      (keys(%{$self->{equation}{variables}}))[0] || 'x';
00203 }
00204 
00205 
00206 #
00207 #  Handle derivative by taking derivative of a prime by taking
00208 #  derivative of the prime's value (which is itself a derivative)
00209 #
00210 sub D {
00211   my $self = shift; my $x = shift;
00212   return $self->{op}->D($x)->D($x);
00213 }
00214 
00215 1;
